subject: RE: JUnit for folks who need good testing (was RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy)
msgSnippet: ... failing ... sentence ... much. ... Apology accepted. Guess I was a little bit sensitive when I read your mail... ;) ... Please reread - you will see that
messageBody:
Adam Jack wrote:
> >> If your project has a big problem with core classes
failing
> on a >> regular basis, then maybe you have a
> process/people problem, as
> > opposed to a technical problem.
> >
> > So junit is for folks who don't really need good testing? ;-)
>
> Ilja,
>
>> Adam, I don't fully understand your intent here, but your
sentence
>> does feel overly rude to me. The smiley really doesn't change
much.
>
> Ilja, I was attempting to use sarcasm to make a point, and
> the wink was intended to convey that. I know e-mail is so
> tone flat, so maybe I shouldn't have taken the risk, but I
> was not meaning to be rude. I apologize if that is how it came off.

Apology accepted. Guess I was a little bit sensitive when I read your
mail... ;)

> Also -- if you interpreted this as "junit isn't good", please
> don't. I was replying to J.B saying if I had lots of core
> failures then I had other problems,

Please reread - you will see that he suggested you *might* have other
problems.

> and I was saying ---
> don't folks w/ problems need good testing?

Oh, ok. I accept that you said that, though I still don't hear it from
your original sentence. Thanks for the clarification.

*If* you do have a process/people problem, though, I don't think that
tinkering with Junit is the best solution. The mass of failing tests is
only a symptom, and by trying to fix it with Junit, you will only cure
the symptom, not the real problem. By solving the real problem, the need
to change the way Junit works will vanish. In fact, aggravating the
problem by letting more tests fail due to a single problem might
actually *help* you solve the real problem (by making it more visible).
*If* you do have a process/people problem.

So, tell us more about those failing tests?

Regards, Ilja
